title: BADecker
author: BADecker
content: Where you can click a button on your wallet and place the Btc on hold with regard to a certin currency. Something like a stablecoin without an actual transfer. Then toggle the button back according to the amount of Bitcoin the fiat is worth at that time.Click the button and get a USD connection right in the wallet. Click it again and get Btc at the current price of USD. All based on the funds in your wallet, without a transfer to a USD stablecoin.Save on transfer funds that way.

comments.author: Hatchy
comments.body: It's kind of similar to staking your BTC but using your holding wallet. Such features would be sick as it would make it easy for a lot of users to swap their coins back and forth without the need of a centralized exchange.Though the reason why I still won't prefer this is that, if we are Bitcoin holders and wish to make more profit on the long-term base, we might miss out on the market. You know how volatile the market is.Let's take for instance, when BTC broke the 90-100k mark, it was so surprising as it happened overnight. Imagine using such features and end up not gaining in the bull? Let's say you had BTC when the price was $48k and you use such features to hold your coin in USDT. Then the price moved from $48k to $100k, you would have missed out on the bull and if you finally unlock your coins back to BTC at $100k, you would have less BTC because it's going to convert back to you at the current market price.Then the reverse would be the case if you use the same feature and the price breaks down on a bear, from $48k to $30k, when you finally convert it back, you would have more BTC worth than you have held. But what's the probability of BTC going down to such a price than moving forward? It might be a nice feature, but I don't think it would be profitable the way you think of it.

comments.author: Darker45
comments.body: May I know the relevance? If I were to put my BTC on hold with regard to a certain currency, why wouldn't I hold the amount in that currency instead? If that is for convenience, the ability to shift back and forth to Bitcoin and a certain fiat, I guess we might have regulatory problems in the process. Using a centralized exchange doesn't mean I can use all available fiat it is supporting. If it's simply a toggle function, is that comparable to a swap? At least with a swap function, you have the freedom to choose the specific amount you wish to convert. If you're talking about an instant toggle between fiat and BTC, that sounds a bit disadvantageous for users because (1) you'll have to involve your entire wallet balance and (2) there will surely be a certain spread, which means you just can't shift between the two anytime without possible losses.

comments.body: Quote from: BADecker on February 16, 2025, 08:34:13 AMQuote from: Darker45 on February 16, 2025, 07:30:35 AM~snip~No transfer fees. Hold the wallet on your desktop. Fast moves. Complete control.Bitcoin only goes up or down. This only moves Bitcoin in or out as you desire.It would be nice to have this, but I don't know if this is possible. In the first place, will there ever be a wallet which supports fiat that's completely under your control? I doubt it. At most, you'll have to use a stablecoin. Secondly, will there ever be a crypto-to-fiat conversion and vice versa without any fees to pay or spread to cover? In certain centralized exchanges, there are P2P crypto-to-fiat and vice versa exchange features that have zero fees, except perhaps those that your banks charge you. But you can't have complete control in this setup. In decentralized setups like Bisq, you will pay fees. I guess the function you have in mind isn't existent, at least not yet. But it seems you oversimplify Bitcoin's movements. Even if certain wallets or exchanges support this, it doesn't mean you'll make profit out of Bitcoin's ups and downs and your ability to instantly get in or out of Bitcoin.

comments.author: Rustam Meraj
comments.body: This sounds like very useful and money saving feature. Basically you are talking about system inside wallet that lets you temporarily connect value of your Bitcoin to regular currency like USD without actually changing it to stablecoin. With this we protect ourself from big price changes and avoid paying fees to move money around. With clicking button you can easily switch between seeing value of your Bitcoin in Bitcoin or in USD based on current exchange rate. This feature would be especially helpful for people who want to keep track of their Bitcoin in relation to regular currencies without wasting money on unnecessary transfer fees.

comments.author: Mia Chloe
comments.body: Quote from: BADecker on February 16, 2025, 06:54:40 AMWhere you can click a button on your wallet and place the Btc on hold with regard to a certin currency. Something like a stablecoin without an actual transfer. Then toggle the button back according to the amount of Bitcoin the fiat is worth at that time..........Okay now basically if I understand what you're trying to say you are looking to create a transaction probably a signed one and then not broadcast it till you are actually ready to make the transaction it's feasible and seems quite similar to Freezing transactions on some wallets.Totally signing and broadcasting a transaction may have fit in too but there are two major setbacks to that one is the fact that the receiving party can also speed up the transaction using CPFP. Also another problem is even if you calculate the time of arrival of that transaction with the current MEMPOOL rates, it wouldn't be accurate since average transaction fees on the mempool are not stable.
